metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This case challenged the decision of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to terminate plaintif...

target:
This case challenged the decision of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to terminate plaintiffs’ environmental grants without notice or substantive reason. These grants, awarded in 2024 under the Biden Administration, comprised $8 million given directly to each plaintiff and access to a further $52 million for plaintiffs to distribute among other community-based environmental initiatives in their respective cities. In February 2025—under the Trump Administration—plaintiffs each received notices that their grants had been terminated. These notices of termination were strictly boilerplate and did not include any specific allegations of wrongdoing on the part of plaintiffs; plaintiffs thus alleged the EPA violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and due process. Included in this boilerplate was an EPA “priority” that it withhold funds from groups that participate in DEI initiatives; plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Clean Water Act’s requirement that grant funds be used to aid underserved communities. Plaintiffs also alleged that it was a violation of the First Amendment for the Trump Administration to terminate their grants based on a difference of views regarding DEI initiatives.

Plaintiffs, three nonprofit and philanthropic organizations, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland on April 2, 2025. Plaintiffs are based in Baltimore, Minneapolis, and Seattle. The lawsuit named the EPA and its Administrator, Lee Zeldin, as defendants. Plaintiffs sought postponement and setting aside of the grant terminations under the APA; a declaration that the Clean Air Act prevented the EPA from choosing to withhold funds from DEI-friendly organizations; a declaration that the grant terminations were unconstitutional; a preliminary and permanent injunction requiring the EPA to reinstate plaintiffs’ terminated grants and preventing it from terminating or suspending any funding to plaintiffs; and attorneys’ fees. The case was assigned to Judge Adam B. Abelson.

On June 17, 2025, the court granted plaintiffs summary judgment with respect to their APA claims, setting aside the EPA’s termination of their grants. The court found that even though the EPA possessed some discretion to advance its policy agenda, it was not allowed to disregard statutory requirements surrounding the grant program. Moreover, even if the agency could so contradict the expressed will of Congress, the court held that the EPA's failure to supply adequate justification for its course of action required it to set aside the grant terminations. The court declined to reach plaintiffs’ constitutional claims. This constituted the final judgment of the district court.

Defendants appealed the district court's summary judgment to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit on July 16, 2025.

This case is ongoing.

These notices of termination were strictly boilerplate and did not include any specific allegations of wrongdoing on the part of plaintiffs; plaintiffs thus alleged the EPA violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and due process. Included in this boilerplate was an EPA “priority” that it withhold funds from groups that participate in DEI initiatives; plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Clean Water Act’s requirement that grant funds be used to aid underserved communities. Plaintiffs also alleged that it was a violation of the First Amendment for the Trump Administration to terminate their grants based on a difference of views regarding DEI initiatives.

annotation.explanation: Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claim challenging the EPA’s termination of grants and seeking postponement and setting aside under the APA.
Due process claim (constitutional) challenging the termination of grants without notice or substantive reason.
First Amendment claim alleging unconstitutional termination based on disagreement over DEI initiatives.
Statutory claim under the Clean Water Act asserting the EPA’s DEI-related funding priority violated the Act’s requirement to aid underserved communities.
Administrative Procedure Act (APA)

annotation.explanation: Defendant: Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
EPA terminated plaintiffs’ environmental grants without notice or substantive reason.

In 2024, under the Biden Administration, each plaintiff received $8 million directly and access to an additional $52 million to distribute to community-based environmental initiatives in their cities.

In February 2025, under the Trump Administration, EPA sent boilerplate termination notices lacking specific wrongdoing and stating an EPA priority to withhold funds from groups participating in DEI initiatives.

Plaintiffs claimed violations of the APA and due process, alleged conflict with the Clean Water Act’s requirement to aid underserved communities, and alleged First Amendment violations based on viewpoint discrimination regarding DEI.

On April 2, 2025, three nonprofit/philanthropic organizations based in Baltimore, Minneapolis, and Seattle filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the EPA and Administrator Lee Zeldin.

Relief sought included postponement and vacatur of terminations under the APA, a declaration that the Clean Air Act bars withholding from DEI-friendly groups, a declaration of unconstitutionality, preliminary and permanent injunctions to reinstate and prevent suspension/termination of funding, and attorneys’ fees.
The case was assigned to Judge Adam B. Abelson.

Relief and motions sought included postponement/setting aside under the APA, declaratory judgments (statutory and constitutional), a preliminary and permanent injunction to reinstate and prevent suspension/termination of funding, and attorneys’ fees.
